drawing package

Submodules

drawing.drawing module

class drawing.drawing.Drawing(ser: Serial = None, com_port: str = None, baud_rate: int = 115200, robot: Mirobot_UART = None, min_x: float = 200, min_y: float = -50, max_x: float = 300, max_y: float = 50, z: float = None)[source]

Bases: object

__init__(ser: Serial = None, com_port: str = None, baud_rate: int = 115200, robot: Mirobot_UART = None, min_x: float = 200, min_y: float = -50, max_x: float = 300, max_y: float = 50, z: float = None)[source]

Initializing drawing helper. Will use serial in following order: ser, com_port and baud_rate, robot

Parameters:

  • ser (serial.Serial, optional) – Existing serial

  • com_port (str, optional) – Serial port (default: None)

  • baud_rate (int, optional) – Baud rate (default: 115200)

  • robot (Mirobot_UART, optional) – Existing Wlkata robot instance (default: None)

  • min_x (float, optional) – Minimum x coordinate (default: None)

  • min_y (float, optional) – Minimum y coordinate (default: None)

  • max_x (float, optional) – Maximum x coordinate (default: None)

  • max_y (float, optional) – Maximum y coordinate (default: None)

  • z (float, optional) – Z coordinate (default: None)

Examples

>>> serial1 = serial.Serial(port='/dev/tty.usbserial-1120', baudrate=115200)
>>> draw1 = Drawing(serial1)

>>> draw2 = Drawing(com_port='/dev/tty.usbserial-1120')

>>> serial1 = serial.Serial(port='COM3', baudrate=115200)
>>> MT4_1 = wlkatapython.MT4_UART(serial1)
>>> MT4_1.init(serial1, -1)
>>> draw3 = Drawing(robot=MT4_1)
Raises:

Exception – If serial port or baud_rate is not valid

Draw the plot based on points_groups

edges_from_image(image_path: str, smoothness: float = 0.0001, binary_threshold: int = 127, method: int = 3, blur: bool = True, edge_detection_threshold1: int = 100, edge_detection_threshold2: int = 200) → list[list[list[tuple[Any, Any]]]][source]

Extract edges from image and approximate them with line segments based on smoothness.

Parameters:

  • image_path (str) – Input image path.

  • smoothness (float, optional) – Smoothness parameter. Higher values simplify edges. (default: 0.0001)

  • binary_threshold (int, optional) – Binary threshold for edge detection. (default: 127)

  • method (int, optional) – Contour retrieval method. Options: cv2.RETR_TREE (default): Retrieve both inner and outer edges. cv2.RETR_EXTERNAL: Retrieve only the outer edges.

  • blur (bool, optional) – Whether to apply Gaussian blur before edge detection. (default: True)

  • edge_detection_threshold1 (int, optional) – Lower threshold for Canny edge detection. (default: 100)

  • edge_detection_threshold2 (int, optional) – Upper threshold for Canny edge detection. (default: 200)

Examples

Basic usage with a sample image:

>>> draw1 = Drawing(com_port="/dev/tty.usbserial-1120")
>>> draw1.edges_from_image("image.jpg")

Specifying all parameters:

>>> draw1.edges_from_image("image.jpg", smoothness=0.01, binary_threshold=127, method=cv2.RETR_EXTERNAL, blur=False, edge_detection_threshold1=50, edge_detection_threshold2=150)
Returns:

List of line segment groups, where each group corresponds to edges in a contour

extract_points_groups(line_segments_groups: list[list[tuple[int, int]]] = None) → list[list[tuple[int, int]]][source]

Extract end points from list of edge segments

Parameters:

line_segments_groups (list[list[tuple[int, int]]], optional) – List of line segments groups. (default: None)

Returns:

List of points groups, where each group corresponds to points in a contour

invert_point_groups(groups: list[list[tuple[Any, Any]]] = None, rotation: int = 0) → list[list[tuple[Any, Any]]][source]

Invert points to make it view correctly

Parameters:

  • groups (list[list[tuple[Any, Any]]], optional) – List of points groups. (default: None)

  • rotation (int, optional) – Number of 90 degree clockwise rotations. (default: 0)

Returns:

List of points groups, where each group corresponds to points in a contour after inverting

resize_point_groups(groups: list[list[tuple[Any, Any]]] = None, keep_aspect_ratio: bool = True, border: float | tuple[float, float] = 5) → list[list[tuple[float, float]]][source]

Resize points to make it view correctly

Parameters:

  • groups (list[list[tuple[Any, Any]]], optional) – List of points groups. (default: None)

  • keep_aspect_ratio (bool, optional) – Whether to keep aspect ratio. (default: True)

  • border (Union[int, float, tuple[float, float]], optional) – Border size. (default: 5)

Returns:

List of points groups, where each group corresponds to points in a contour after resizing
